node.title: Have policymakers failed workers since the 1990s? Or have they got things right?
node.alt: Employees working on laptops in an office.
node.description: Will Australia's inflation-targeting regime need a reboot on the other side of the pandemic?
node.content:
["I want to show\u00a0you something.", "This goes to the heart of Australia's macro-economic management.", "It determines the quality of life of millions of us, and the forecasts in the\u00a0federal budget,\u00a0but few people talk\u00a0about it \u2014 except econocrats (those in society who believe the main purpose of politics is improving the economy and that economic policymaking has become a technocratic process).", "So let's have a look at it.", "
A holy grail of economics
", "For generations, one of the holy grails of economics has been to find the answer to\u00a0this problem:", "And for the last 30 years, policymakers have believed that part of the secret is to keep inflation under control.", "Why would that be?", "Because, if you keep prices\u00a0growing slowly, you're giving producers and consumers the gift of time.", "If people come to believe that prices are only going to be rising\u00a0gently, they won't feel rushed to make\u00a0investment and spending decisions, and they won't fret about inflation depleting the value of their savings deposits.", "It means the economy will have a better chance of growing at a sustainable pace, because it will avoid\u00a0some damaging fits and starts in activity.", "It's why so\u00a0many countries have adopted inflation targeting regimes since the 1990s.", "See below.", "", "
Australia was one of the first countries in the world to adopt an inflation-targeting regime(Source: International Monetary\u00a0Fund (2017), \"Inflation Targeting: Holding the Line\")
", "Notice how Australia was one of the first to do so?", "After the pain of \"stagflation\" in the 1970s, policymakers restructured Australia's economy in the 1980s and 1990s.", "The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA)\u00a0adopted\u00a0an official inflation target in 1993, aiming\u00a0to keep inflation within a range of 2 to 3 per cent, on average, over the cycle.", "Many economists think it helped\u00a0Australia's\u00a0economy to record\u00a0nearly 30 years of uninterrupted growth before the COVID-19\u00a0pandemic hit in 2020.", "But I want to show you something else.", "
Where does growth come\u00a0from?
", "Our inflation-targeting regime sits inside a larger framework.", "Think about economic growth\u00a0itself.", "Have you ever wondered where it comes from?", "For hundreds of years, economists have known that the building blocks of economic activity are land, labour and capital.", "Those building blocks are the inputs we use\u00a0to produce goods and services to make an economic profit.", "Now, let's say you have a fair idea of how many goods and services your economy has been producing\u00a0in recent\u00a0years.", "Could it have produced more comfortably?", "If so, it means your economy hasn't been producing at its\u00a0potential level.", "The potential level of output is the theoretical frontier of your economy's productive capacity.", "It's the maximum level of\u00a0goods and services your economy should be able to produce without creating destabilising inflationary pressures.", "You can visualise it this way.\u00a0", "See the image below, where an economy's actual\u00a0output\u00a0is shifting\u00a0around\u00a0its potential output over time.", "", "
In economics, the \"business cycle\" refers to fluctuations in economic growth relative to growth in potential output(Source: Reserve Bank of Australia, \"Economic Growth\" explainer)
", "Here's how to make sense of the graph.", "Whenever\u00a0there's a gap between the potential output line and the actual output line, it's called an \"output gap\".", "Now, see that\u00a0bit where the economy's actual output is running above its potential output?", "That's a situation in which the output gap is positive.", "When you have a positive output gap, inflation will be rising because your economy's running above its capacity.", "In the 1970s, when\u00a0Australia's economy was hit by stagflation,\u00a0the economy's actual output ended up running well above its potential output, according to the theory.", "It saw inflation soar, and economic activity slow\u00a0down.", "Now, see that bit on the graph where\u00a0the\u00a0economy's actual output is running below its potential?", "That's a situation in which the output gap is negative.", "When you have a negative output gap, there's considerable slack in your labour market and wage and inflation pressures are really weak.", "That's when the economy\u00a0would benefit from policies that deliberately boost demand and lift activity back\u00a0to its potential.", "In the wake of the 2007-09 financial crisis, Australia's economy has been stuck in such a hole, according to the theory.", "The output gap has been negative for years, and\u00a0it's seen wages growth and inflation drop to record lows.", "
But can you see the unobservables?
", "Now, this bit's really important.", "What I've told you is just a theory.", "Why? Because an economy's level of potential output is actually unobservable.\u00a0", "Economists can't say with certainty what an economy's potential output is. They\u00a0can only try to estimate it.", "However, since they really want to keep inflation under control, they also want to prevent economic\u00a0activity maxing out, so\u00a0they\u00a0try to estimate where they think the economy's level of potential output probably is.", "Once they've done that, they can try to keep economic activity close to that level\u00a0without drifting too high above it.", "This way of thinking is mainstream.", "It lies at the heart of Australia's modern macro-economic management.", "For instance, when Treasury officials produce their projections for the federal budget \u2014 for things such as\u00a0wages, inflation, employment, and tax revenue \u2014\u00a0they're relying on their estimates of potential output and the output gap.", "Could there be any problems with the approach?", "Well, since it\u00a0relies\u00a0on estimates of unobservable phenomena it's vulnerable to miscalculation.", "Could it explain why\u00a0the\u00a0forecasts for wages and inflation (from both Treasury and the RBA) have been so wrong over the last decade?", "
Do\u00a0the unobservables exist?
", "And here's the final thing.", "There are actually two vital numbers that sit at the heart of Australia's macro-economic management framework that are unobservable.", "The first is the estimate of potential output.", "But the second is the\u00a0estimate\u00a0of \"full employment\".", "Since the 1980s, Australia's econocrats have asserted that there's a level of unemployment that's \"natural\" for prevailing conditions.", "According to their theory,\u00a0an economy can be in full employment when the unemployment rate is 3 per cent, or 5\u00a0per cent, or 7\u00a0per cent.", "It all depends.", "They say the\u00a0economy is in \"full employment\" whenever wages and inflation are threatening to lift too quickly.", "And they call that\u00a0level of \"full employment\"\u00a0the\u00a0NAIRU \u2014\u00a0non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment.", "However, the\u00a0NAIRU is unobservable.", "They can't say for certain\u00a0where it is.", "No matter. Their estimate of the (unobservable) NAIRU is necessary for the calculation that produces their estimate of the economy's potential output, which is also unobservable.", "See the calculation for \"potential real GDP\" below.", "", "So, you have two very important numbers\u00a0which\u00a0impact the quality of\u00a0life of millions of us, but which are highly theoretical and unobservable.\u00a0", "This is the framework that dominates our economic policymaking.", "It\u00a0puts a priority on keeping inflation under control.", "Our inflation-targeting regime supported the economy's record run of growth after the '90s recession.", "But it has also been in place as wages growth and inflation have fallen to record low levels in recent years,\u00a0and\u00a0as\u00a0productivity growth has dropped to the slowest pace in 60 years.", "It's also been in place while the\u00a0labour force has become increasingly casualised, as under-utilisation has hit record highs, and as the bargaining power of Australia's workers has collapsed.", "Does the framework need an overhaul on the other side of the pandemic? Or will it carry on unchanged?", "At any rate, on Thursday this week, Treasury will be publishing its mid-year update of the numbers in the federal budget.", "Its economic projections\u00a0will be relying on its estimates of potential output and the NAIRU.", "Now you know what that means."]
